content: a practically hyperbolic dishcloth hyperbolic crochet was first descibed by daina taimina and david henderson less than a decade ago see here http //www math cornell edu/~dwh/papers/crochet/crochet html and it s been used to make amazing things ever since see here http //www theiff org/reef/index html these dishcloths harness its beauty for a more utilitarian purpose with a hyperbolic ruffle surrounding a flat center the result is a lightweight cloth with a large surface area and a tendency to fold itself in your hand just the way you would want it to without any effort at all enjoy materials approximately an ounce of worsted weight cotton and a size h 5 00 mm crochet hook 1 stitch marker tapestry needle for weaving ends abbreviations u s notation chain chain stitch half_double_crochet half_double_crochet single_crochet single_crochet slip_stitch slip_stitch notes this pattern is worked in a spiral do not join rounds the hyperbolic portion is formed by holding the rate of increase constant in this particular case by working an increase in every third stitch this means that some rounds do not come out even i generally deal with this by using a marker and simply moving it as appropriate to mark the beginning of the round but i ve quantified each hyperbolic round below if you prefer to count i d still consider a stitch marker a necessity though just to make it easier to keep your place finished size approximately 6 5 inches 16 5 cm in diameter the pattern round 1 chain 3 7 half_double_crochet in furthest chain from hook 8
